data.title: Afghanistan – Violence Against Women Law at Risk
data.text:
The Afghan Women’s Network

is demanding that no amendment or changes should be made in the law on

elimination of violence against women.

The Afghan Women’s Network

said that the Parliament is trying to bring some amendments in the law on

elimination of violence against women which will prove to be detrimental for

the Afghan women and put front some serious challenges.

Recently the law on

elimination of violence against women has been tabled in the Parliament for

discussion.

The planned changes in the law have surprised the Afghan Women’s Network.

Mahbobah Saraj, a member of

Afghan Women’s Network said, “Any kind of compromise on women rights will

put in danger the last ten years of achievements.”

The law on elimination of

violence against women has been called as the most powerful law supporting the

rights of women in the country after the Constitution.

This law lists crimes such as

under age forced marriage, selling and buying of women/girls under the pretext

of marriage, self-immolation, beating, raping and various other forms of

violence against women.

Summarizing the probable

amendments in this law, Sorya Sobrang, a member of the Afghan Women’s Network

said, “It is perceived that some amendments would come regarding women’s

marriages, right of education, safe houses for women and some other issues. For

example in the current law it has been mentioned that every girl aged 18 years

can decide about her future but in the changes it has been mentioned that if the

family of the girl or her lawyer says that it is not going to harm her then she

can’t marry.”

Heather Barr a member of

Human Rights Watch said, “Even though we are not satisfied with the

non-implementation of this law but having this law is a sign of progress and

any kind of changes in this law would be a disaster for the Afghan women. The

Parliament should work towards strengthening this law and not weaken it.”
